headline: Ohio constitutional carry bill advances
author: Tom Knighton
sentences:
Meanwhile, lawmakers inched forward on a bill to relax penalties for people carrying concealed weapons in prohibited places, and another restricting how local police can limit firearms sales or transportations during a “riot.”
On Tuesday, the House Government Oversight Committee reviewed Senate Bill 215, which would allow anyone 21 and up to carry without a permit so long as they lawfully possess the gun in question.

The governor has declined to take a position on the bill in public statements but told the Buckeye Firearms Association in writing during the 2018 primary that he would support a constitutional carry bill.
The state House is teeing up a final passage vote on legislation to remove training and background check requirements to carry a concealed firearm in Ohio.
Should the House pass the legislation again (they passed the same language contained in a different bill last year), it would go to the desk of GOP Gov.
Then again, if not, it’ll be interesting to know who the next governor of Ohio will be and how much of a landslide they’ll win by in 2022.
And while he’s pushed for his gun control bill, he hasn’t lied about supporting any legislation only to veto it so far as I’m aware.
If DeWine says he’ll back a constitutional carry bill and doesn’t, then he might as well not even bother running for reelection.
When this year first started, I didn’t think we’d see significant movement on constitutional carry from the state of Ohio.
He’s been pushing his own anti-gun agenda, though one that doesn’t go nearly as far as anti-gunners would like.
Current law requires Ohioans to undergo eight hours of training and a background check to obtain a CCW permit.
However, even those who don’t see guns as the key issue should look at DeWine skeptically if that happens.
Republicans in the House passed a near identical bill last year, rendering passage more likely than not.
If DeWine signs the bill–assuming it passes, of course–then I’ll be happy to be wrong about the man.
After all, what else will he say he’ll sign, only to change his mind when it comes across his desk.
If you haven’t been able to tell I’m less than trusting when it comes to DeWine, well, I’m not.
He was way too quick to push for gun control after the shooting in Dayton for my comfort.
Mike DeWine isn’t exactly the most pro-gun Republican in public office these days.
Whether DeWine supports this constitutional carry bill or not remains to be seen.
There’s zero reason for any pro-gun voter to trust him to keep his word.
So no, I didn’t expect much out of an Ohio constitutional carry push.
But, he’s also a far cry from being Phil Murphy of New Jersey.
The full House passed it in a 60-32 party line vote.
The committee passed it in an 8-5 party line vote.
It’s up for another hearing Wednesday.
I’d like to take DeWine’s word for it.
Yet, it seems I was mistaken.
After all, Gov.
I truly would.
Mike DeWine.
